segments.text: Hello and welcome to the Slate Political Gabbfest for Thursday, August 16th, the Unhinged
Me Now edition.
I am Emily Basilan in basically for David Plots, who is off, I'm not sure where David
is, maybe he's in Vermont.
Anyway, never fear, I am here with John Dickerson of CBS This Morning.
Hey John.
Hi.
David Powers from CNN, whose title I forgot to ask before we start.
I can't believe this.
I can't believe this.
What's your official title?
A political analyst.
Excellent.
Thanks for having me.
Oh, we're so glad you're here.
On this week's show, we have three topics as usual for you followed by cocktail chatter.
First topic, Trump has been dueling this week with his former aide Omarosa Manigault Newman.
She's teasing her book.
He's getting mad at her.
There's confirmed discussion of non-disclosure agreements to work in the White House in the
air.
So we will chew through all of that.
We'll be distracted by it, just like everyone else in the world.
Our second topic will be the primary election results this week, which saw winners among
Republicans who closely embraced Donald Trump.
And a different story from Democrats.
The most interesting part to me was about minority candidates, especially African Americans,
happening in majority White districts, including in my home state of Connecticut.
And our third topic, a star feminist philosopher at NYU has been found to have sexually harassed
a male graduate that finding comes from NYU.
And this is a story about Title IX, the law that is supposed to create gender equality
in education settings, really turning Title IX on its head.
And so we'll talk about that case and what, and about the support for this philosopher
from other feminist academics.
And of course, we'll have cocktail chatter.
Omarosa Managult Newman is on every single talk show in the world, flogging tapes that
she has.
She's done, I would say, like a brilliant job of teasing her book and separating out these
tapes into different dollops of news.
Clearly, she knows what she's doing or someone she works with knows what they're doing.
The biggest sort of explosive accusation here is that Trump, the she thinks that Trump
has used the worst racial epithet about Black people, that there's supposedly a tape
of this.
The accusation went from the idea that there was this tape floating around to Omarosa
saying she'd heard of the tape.
And then she has a tape of two Republican operatives talking about this possibility during the
campaign.
So Kirsten, how much attention should we pay to this?
Omarosa has her own sort of credibility issues.
She obviously backed the president incredibly strongly for a long time.
She's been one of the principal African Americans to play that role for him.
Now very predictably, she's making a move away from him to get her attention for her
book.
How much would it matter if Donald Trump, if we do have a tape of Donald Trump saying
the end word?
Well, if I was Queen of the World, there would be nobody interviewing her.
I am very bothered by the fact that the media is playing into this circus which was originally
created by Donald Trump.
So it's not surprising that somebody he hired is now adding to the circus and using the
media, something like The Today Show, which is typically pretty hard to get on to, to
listen to somebody who, as you said, has zero credibility whatsoever.
I mean, even after she left, she was defending him saying he wasn't a racist.
In terms of the end word tape, I mean, obviously it matters if he said something like that,
but it won't matter to the people who support him.
I don't think it would have any political impact whatsoever.
Moreover, there's plenty of evidence for Omarosa if she was paying attention that the president
is racist.
So he talks, the way he talks in such dehumanizing terms about immigrants, you know, the very
fine people at the Charlottesville, you know, protest or what March, whatever you want
to call it, which she set upset her so much.
But yet a year later, she was still in the White House.
Also, she's pretending that she saw the light when she was fired.
In fact, she has a tape of herself getting fired.
So everything about it just smacks of somebody who's trying to make a buck and get rich over
the fact that she got fired.
John, you can't dispute any of that.
I think the, so the question here is whether there's any value to the information from
somebody who has serious credibility issues.
And one piece of information that is interesting to consider is why a person like this who
has these credibility issues was a top officially in the Trump administration, why she had high
security clearance, and what this tells us about the world in which the president operates,
which I think, and the White House world itself, which I think is a story worth repeating.
I think probably also those people who think race is at the center of both the way the
president was elected and the way he runs his presidency.
I think they could make a case that Omarosa aside, having a central conversation about
the president and his relationship with race is one that should be going on all the time.
Instead of the extent that the surface is that, that that's not a bad thing.
I think going back to the idea of how he runs his White House.
So we actually interviewed Omarosa and I said, why should anybody trust you or listen to
you given the fact that you were taping not just when you were fired, which she said was
in order to kind of cover or have a record so that they couldn't smear her.
She would have a recording of this.
And she, but I said, if you were taping even when during the campaign, and she said, well,
they were, they lie so much, you know, I was protecting myself.
So just stop for a minute.
And yet, did she call them out of the class?
Here's the right.
Here's a person who has paid taxpayer money to speak about the virtues of the president
and the people who worked in the administration who privately was so questioning the virtues
of those people that she was making tape recordings of them because she knew ultimately there
would be some kind of Armageddon like this one that she is, she is kicked off.
So I think that that's, that's, that's new in the way White House has run.
It's just a kind of another extraordinary thing about this week, which isn't over yet
as she on Thursday is planning more of these, some, more of these disclosures.
I mean, it strikes me, Amos is a type, right?
The tail telling a former aide who comes forward to shed light on the inner workings
of the White House, but she's like such a deeply cynical version of this type, which
is entirely fitting with this White House that you would have someone, John, who's doing
exactly the dance you were describing, but then, you know, also because she was the
Black woman close to Donald Trump, she was providing this particular kind of cover for
him.
And if it's true, and I think we should talk through this a little more, if it's true that
a tape of Donald Trump saying the N word wouldn't matter, Amarosa made a small contribution
along the way to the, to the not mattering to the kind of political cover for Donald
Trump that allowed White people and people in general who want to let him off the hook
for race to look at her as an example, a kind of symbol of his personal tolerance of African
Americans.
Well, let me ask you this, either one of you this question, which is in the moral balance
as if you can even do this kind of equation, but I'll tee it up and you can tell me it's
a dumb question, which is worse to have used the word and what we don't know the context
and all the rest or to have been the nation's chief birther for five years or so, or however
many years it was carrying out a system systematic and prolonged and aggressive campaign to suggest
that the president, the African American previous African American president was illegitimate,
which we all know, which is not something that needs to be disclosed in a tape.
It's happened all in real time in front of everyone.
Totally cares.
Well, I mean, I still would always for me the N word is the sort of, you know, the worst
of the worst of things that you can do because there's just no, there are people who could
try to somehow justify the birther stuff.
You know, I don't agree with it, but there's just nobody that can say using the N word
is ever anything but viciously racist, right?
So, but the broader point I think is what you're making is we already have tons of evidence
about his racial animosity, you know, at best in the way that he talks about people, the
asshole countries, the fact that he, why can't we have more Norwegians, you know, in
the country.
And so I think that he has shown this time and time again.
And so what does it really add in terms of value, what Omarosa is sharing?
And I guess my concern is that I, maybe I'm wrong and, you know, maybe John, you can
correct me on this.
I just feel like there was a time that she wouldn't have gotten the media attention from
the main, like the really high quality shows, you know, that the, like your show wouldn't
have been having her on, but maybe I'm wrong, you know, and that, that, that somehow Donald
Trump, this is part of his whole, what he's doing to this country is just turning into
spectacle where we're talking about this and we're not talking about, you know, things
that I think are actually important that are actually harmful to the country.
In the end, what does Omarosa really add to that?
Right.
Well, it depends because in a previous administration, this would seem, let's imagine it's a previous
administration that operates along traditional norms.
She would be bizarre.
This would be, but this would, but her disclosures would also be an opt.
We should know.
Revelatory.
Yeah, they'd be extraordinary.
They would be so such a departure.
So the question is, so I don't know.
I mean, I, I'm, but don't you, I know you think though, I definitely agree with your larger
point, which is that this is a part of the freak show that, that, and I think we've
wrestled, I've wrestled the entire press has wrestled with the amount of the, the freak
show that needs to be covered because he's, this is the president of the United States.
This is a senior advisor to the president of the United States making extraordinary claims.
And yet that shouldn't blot out the sun.
Right.
I guess the only thing I would say is if this had happened under Obama, which of course
it never would have, cause they never would have hired somebody like this, but let's just
say they did.
They hired somebody who was kind of sketchy who had a history of, yeah.
Showy thing.
Yeah.
Kind of sketchy and had a history of creating drama.
And for whatever reason, they were a family friend.
Who knows?
They get in the White House and then they leave and they're disgruntled.
I feel like most reporters would have looked at them and said, this is a kind of disgruntled
crazy person.
We're not going to take them seriously.
Right.
But yet with Omarosa, she has this long history of being dishonest and of creating drama.
And yet we're saying like, oh, well, let's listen to her.
Even though a lot of the stuff that she's saying, frankly, is stuff that was reported.
So she's saying, oh, well, talking about the light switches, which Maggie Habermann had
reported on and kind of repackaging stuff.
And it's like, what is she really saying that that's new?
Even the N word tape we all had heard about, right?
So I don't, like, how do we know she even actually heard it?
I mean, I just find her so uncredible.
Here's one thing I disagree with you about, or maybe I'm hoping to disagree with you about.
I wonder if a tape of the N word would make a difference to some Trump supporters because
for a lot of people, I think mostly a lot of White people, there's a shared feeling.
And I, you know, Kirsten, it sounds like you and I don't mean this in any sort of critical
way, but like you were just expressing it that there's just something about that insult
in that word.
It's a third rail and it's, and people judge it as like indicative of a white person's
personal prejudice and animosity and vitriol in a way that almost nothing else seems to
accomplish.
I mean, to me, I would have answered the birth or question differently.
Like I think that that was tremendously destructive for President Obama, obviously, but for people
of color in the country, and I think you can point to Trump's dehumanizing language
calling women dogs also is destructive.
But there's something about, I think for, we fasten on the N word is like this epithet
that nobody is allowed to say.
And so if you dare to say it, that means that you are like a true racist.
And then I think it would be hard for some members of Congress to like keep counting and
saying everything they've counted and so far.
It would just be so clear and simple.
An expression of racism.
I guess I mean, I agree with what you said about the N word being the ultimate, exactly
that.
There's just no question.
You can't, there's no way to dress it up like I use it in a way that's acceptable.
I just think it's all out there already and these people in Congress have decided to still
stand by him and that I think there's a very, very cold, like, you know, as people have
pointed out, quality to this where nothing you say or nothing he says or does seems
to make any difference.
I mean, I just, there's just so many, I mean, taking children from their parents, you know,
I mean, it's just, there's, there just seems to be nothing that shifts.
Now maybe it might affect an independent.
That's true.
Right.
Some people are shifting, right?
Yeah.
Yeah.
I mean, I think we'll talk about this in our second topic.
Yeah.
I mean, it's clearly affected the number of people who are running on the Democratic side,
the kind of people who are running the kind of people that are being elevated by the,
Democratic Party and some of the behavior in, in the Republican Party, the, so many we
should track on the topic.
Well, I'm not quite ready to move, although we will in a minute.
So I want to bring up a couple of new examples of norm breaking, norm violating.
So we learn from this episode something we had actually Ruth Marcus had reported months
ago that White House employees are being asked to sign on disclosure agreements in a way
that totally breaks with tradition.
There have been these kinds of agreements in the past, only about classified information.
These seem to be much broader NDAs that essentially are lifted from language that the Trump organization
used and would seem to be totally unconstitutional at odds with law.
So we've got that going on.
And then this week we have Trump revoking the security clearance for the former CIA director,
John O'Brennan.
And Trump said this because of the Russia investigation and because Brennan has been
a Trump critic.
And these both seem to be like just deeply troubling.
What else is there to say?
The idea of muzzling White House staffers so they can't discuss non classified information
when they leave will learn even less about internal deliberations, even if it's just
an intimidation tactic and it's useless.
And then taking away Brennan's security clearance is obviously sending a message to that if
you criticize the president from outside the government, you're going to lose this sort
of position of honor that came with that access and you won't be available anymore as a source
of advice to people who are still in the government, which is traditionally why we allowed people
to hold on to their security clearances after they left.
John, what do you think the significance of all this is?
Well, the retaliatory significance, especially what strikes me is a little bit, I mean, I
was going to say abnormal, but it's such a hardware to use these days is that if you're
a president who's under investigation for obstructing justice and trying to get in the way of an
investigation into Russia to then take retaliatory action because of the Russia investigation
seems to me something you just wouldn't want to do.
You might not admit it.
You might not admit it to the Wall Street Journal.
Yeah.
I mean, so it's punishable.
I think Fran Townsend, who's the Homeland Security advisor to President Bush made the
point this morning that this again shows us something about the president.
There is a way to take people's clearances away and there are reasons to do that and
all of that.
But in this case, it was basically the president doing it on a whim, Dan Coats, the director
of the National Intelligence Agency said his comment was or the agency's comment was,
well, the president has ultimate discretion, which is the way we've come to recognize
when somebody is in disagreement with something the president did.
There was reporting that Coats didn't even know the president was going to do this.
So again, it's another instance in which the president, he has authority as the executive
to do this, but there is a system set up which he's blowing through and which is just another
instance in which he's done so.
And this is basically not for national security reasons, but because he doesn't like what
Fran has been saying.
Right.
It must be so satisfying though.
There are a few things as president.
You can just do like ways in which you are actually an imperial figure, pardons are another
one.
And we've seen Trump also use them in a kind of whimsical, unsystem-driven manner.
Kirsten, what are your thoughts about this revoking of Brennan's security clearance?
Well, like you just said, one of the first things I thought of was the pardons, which
is he didn't go through the process that most presidents go through before they pardon
somebody.
I think that the fact that it's imperial is something that appeals to him.
I think Donald Trump likes to behave more like a king or an authoritarian, which is why he
loves authoritarians and cozies up to them.
And so I think that tells us something about him.
And of course, it's very despotic to be a person who tries to punish anybody who criticizes
you.
We have a tradition.
We used to have a tradition for all the problems that we have.
And yes, we had problems before Donald Trump came in in terms of hyper-polarization.
But he is just poured gasoline on the fire because we used to at least be able to say,
yes, we're in different parties or maybe we even run against each other.
Look at Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
He makes his secretary of state after everything that they went through during that election
and really not liking each other very much at the end of it.
And you see that across the aisle as well.
And now what you have with Donald Trump is he can't even say John McCain's name, recognizing
him for a bill that's passed and named after him because John McCain criticizes him even
though he's battling brain cancer.
And he can't just be decent towards people who have served our country, whatever you
think of them, because they've criticized him and now want to revoke their security
clearances.
He's just kind of blowing through norms, right?
That's I think making everything is even more divisive.
And we should also add back to your earlier point, Kirsten, that this is some analysts
of the White House and some people close to it are basically also saying that since this
order was actually signed back in June, July, that the unveiling of it today is a part of
the cycle of attention-
Distraction.
Right.
Distraction.
I suppose distract from Omarosa, although sometimes it's hard to see what distraction
is taking away from which distraction.
I'm just jumpfire after the next.
Yeah.
All right.
On that note, we're going to switch to something that is like, I feel like we can feel clean
about this one pure substance maybe.
Okay.
It's primary season.
So we're going to talk about the party separately.
Let's start with the Republicans.
We have a few examples in the last week of Republicans winning primaries where they're
clearly being rewarded for sticking as closely as possible to Donald Trump.
So in Kansas, Chris Kobach will be the Republican nominee for governor.
He defeated a kind of like mild manner, not exactly incumbent, but the guy who'd shown
up after Sam Brownback became the ambassador.
Kobach is probably best known nationally for being one of the real champions of voter
purges and of the myth essentially that voter fraud is widespread.
He's going to be running in Kansas.
And then we have the Minnesota Republican running for governor will be Jeff Johnson,
not Tim Palente who had criticized Donald Trump and had previously been the governor
of Minnesota.
In Connecticut, there was a three way primary in the GOP and the winner was Bob Steffinowski,
a super rich businessman from the wealthiest part of my state who was also immediately
endorsed by Trump.
So obviously, John, the president is proving ever more that he has a strong hold on Republican
primary voters.
And then of course, the question is whether these folks are going to be viable in the general
election.
Right.
He's 14 for 14, according to the New York Times, since June in his endorsements.
Now that's not to say that once he sprinkles holy water on somebody, they immediately shoot
up the polls.
If you are in the in the slipstream with the kind of Trump view of the world, then you're
going to do well in Republican politics.
And that's why we've seen some of these candidates reform and change their opinions about Donald
Trump, the winning ones.
To me, the most striking thing just in terms of the current history of the Republican Party
was Tim Palente's loss in Minnesota.
Now there were reasons Palente could lose that have nothing to do with Donald Trump.
He went from being a governor to then being a Washington lobbyist.
They're a great thing when outsiders are in to be running as a former lobbyist.
But Palente had criticized President Trump and ultimately after he was defeated, said,
you know, I'm just not a Donald Trump kind of politician.
What's striking to me about that is that in 2010, when Palente was thinking about running
for president, his entire pitch, his mother died when he was 16.
His father was a truck driver.
His entire pitch was, I'm the guy who is the Sam's Club Republican.
I am and understand the forgotten man and woman.
It was the Donald Trump pitch from a kind of intellectual level, not the sort of gut cultural
level, but it was playing.
But like, I am you, the populism of that part of it, which Trump actually, of course, can't
do that.
It was an attempt to go after the exact same message just in a very, very different way.
So now he has been crumpled by the force of Donald Trump in the Republican Party.
And just if we're thinking about where the party has come from and where it's been,
by the way, we're talking about a state like Minnesota too, which is not your traditional
Republican state.
So that to me was one of the most interesting kind of just points along the way in which
the Republican Party is changing.
And I'll shut up now, but we still obviously have the question of the general, which is
obviously quite different than the primary.
I mean, one thing to point out too is Minnesota and Connecticut are not Ruby-Red states by
any means.
Right.
I think it's a risk for them.
And so what is it if Tim Polenty has this story and he's this sort of populist type
of, has a populist type story?
And so what is it that Donald Trump is giving to people that is making them say, I don't
want to Tim Polenty, I want to Chris Cobach.
And to me, it really seems that it's much more about rhetoric than it is about policy.
It's much more about being nasty and putting people down and being kind of extremist.
And like you said with Chris Cobach, I mean, his calling card is basically trying to make
it harder for people of color to vote.
And so it says a lot about the Republican Party that somebody like Tim Polenty is now
out of the mainstream.
And we've seen this over and over where we're told people who are much more conservative
than him are somehow not conservative enough because they're not Trumpy.
And so what does it mean to be Trumpy?
And the only thing I can see is it just means being insulting to people and having no regard
for norms.
And so I think Republicans have to kind of have a reckoning about that.
It's like, is this who the Republican Party wants to be?
That's interesting.
I mean, I feel like some of these candidates don't personally embody that nastiness necessarily.
But getting so cutening to it has its own effect.
And endorsing it.
I'm really curious.
And of course, right.
I mean, even if you're not doing it yourself when you like get right up and snuggle up against
it, it's going to come off on you in some way.
I mean, I'm going to go on for a moment about Connecticut, although I'm about to do that
in another minute.
So it's going to be a lot of Connecticut for the next few minutes.
There was a three way race for the primary.
Stefanowski was the underdog.
Being the next governor of Connecticut is going to be the worst job ever.
We have a huge budget hole.
Our current governor, like a perfectly decent person has like a 16% approval rating.
The Democrats nominated dead Lamont who is a businessman like Stefanowski, but a Democrat.
And it's going to be kind of a weird war to get a position that like will then be totally
thankless.
What's so fascinating for me about Lamont is he ran against Lieberman from the left during
the war.
Beat him.
He's been independent, but if you look at what's happening in the Democratic Party these
days, Lamont was just a little early.
Although he says he's going out again.
And I should say he, he, he, Lamont beat Lieberman in the primary and then Lieberman switched
to one in the general.
So on the Republicans, I just on the general question, one of the things that'll be one
of the things that's interesting to me is you look at a state like Wisconsin, which was
once this kind of interesting place for the new Republican.
This is the new pre-Trump era Republican.
You had Scott Walker very popular, had done things that the base liked in terms of taking
on the unions.
Paul Ryan was in the ascendancy back then having run with Mitt Romney.
People talked about him running for president.
Well, now Ryan is out.
His district is potentially up for grabs.
Walker is in a pickle running for, for governor because he's got to both not criticize the
president, but on the other hand, the president's tariff policies are hurting Wisconsin specifically.
And then you have Tammy Baldwin, who is running against state Senator Lee Vukmir, I think,
is how you pronounce this.
Who has said at one point that Trump was offensive to everyone.
So why does that matter?
Well, she got the nomination.
So she's going to be the Republican.
So what does Tammy Baldwin do?
Does she make Trump an issue in Wisconsin, which is a state that Trump did better than
than anybody was expecting in the general?
Or does she, because of course one of the things for the general election is how much
Democrats in these close races, which will determine the control of the house, make
President Trump an active issue or just let him be the issue for democratic turnout that
he will always be.
Because in part, probably because of the cyclotron we were talking about earlier, which is just
this constant repetition in the news cycle of why Democrats find the president objectionable,
which is as a news matter gets priorities out of whack.
But as a base turnout matter probably keeps people continually motivated with reasons
to turn out.
So I guess my basic question at the end is, what are these people in these tough Senate
races in Trump states?
How much do they actually prosecute Donald Trump, putting him on the ballot and how much
do they let it just happen as a natural in the natural course of politics?
Yeah, that'll be really interesting to watch.
I'm going to put in a short plug for my colleague Dan Kaufman's excellent book, The Fall of
Wisconsin.
I'm going to understand changing politics in Wisconsin.
It's excellent.
So let's talk about the Democrats.
I am totally taken with a race to the west of New Haven, the fifth district in Connecticut.
The Democrats nominated Johanna Hayes, an African American who was a national teacher
of the year, made a biographical video that went viral, that begins with her accepting
her award from President Obama.
She seems like she's kind of lighting things up.
It's a district that is 88% white.
And that is something we haven't seen very much of in this country.
I mean, there are a few examples of it.
We have Mia Love, who's a Republican in Utah representing a mostly white district.
There's a Democratic congresswoman in Delaware named Lisa Blunt-Rachaster.
And there are more of these candidates running this year, nine Democrats running for Congress
in majority white districts, among them are Lauren Underwood, who's running in the 14th
district in Illinois.
So this to me seems like it could be groundbreaking.
Forever, we've had this assumption with research to back it up that black candidates could
only win in majority minority districts.
There's like Voting Rights Act law predicated on that.
Now the research shows that you can have a district that lets minority voters pick the
candidate of their choice with only like 40% minority voting.
It depends on the part of the country, obviously.
But these districts, these races, this race in Connecticut suggests something else entirely.
And I wonder, Karistin, if you feel like this sort of lights a new path for the Democrats
or maybe people are making too big a deal out of it.
Also, a lot of these candidates are women and I wonder what you make of that.
Well, the studies that you're talking about though, they're talking about in
Democratic districts, not just in general districts.
Well, the Voting Rights Act research has to do with like how many, what percentage of
a district has to be minority in terms of either registration or likely voter population
in order for it to satisfy the requirements of the Voting Rights Act that the redistricting
not take away power.
So actually that's something that's not just Democratic districts necessarily.
I was just asking, because the Women's Media Center just had a survey that they had put
out talking about war women being elected, at least in the primaries.
And of course, most of them are Democrats.
And that when you look at US Democrats, US Republicans, are you more likely to vote for
someone because they're women?
For Republicans, that's a non-issue really.
And for Democrats, it's actually a plus, right?
So I'm wondering if now if it's because-
It's like a 10-point advantage, I saw.
Yeah, if it's becoming a plus now to be somebody who is, not just somebody who's bringing another
perspective, which I think is really important to Democrats, but also I think Democrats love
firsts, right?
We want to break down walls, progressives want to break down walls and have new people.
And so that actually makes it a more positive thing.
And I also was thinking back to during the 2008 election, how a lot of people felt like,
oh, well, there's no way Barack Obama, and I know a lot of people on his campaign felt
like there's no way Barack Obama can win Iowa because it's so white.
And then of course, he did.
But it was progressive.
So I think that it depends a lot in where you are.
Although Obama was interesting because he won in Iowa and then won in the general in
Iowa, which was even since it was a swingy state.
But think about Hayes is she's going to win in the general because it's a Democratic
district.
Yeah, I mean, it's funny.
So the race thing is not as-
It seems like-
Not a heavily Democratic district, though, remember.
And the other thing is like it's a very wealthy part of Connecticut.
I mean, it was a scene is this way.
It's true that the person who's leaving the seat is a Democrat and that Cook now has
it in the safely Democratic column.
But historically, Gary Franks in the 90s was an African American Republican who represented
that decision.
But the African Democratic Republicans-
That was a lot-
The 90s was different than where the party started today.
But what's- what is interesting about Hayes is that she has 538s on some analysis of who
